== What is Samba? ==

<nowiki>[[File:SambaLogo.png|Samba Logo|align="left"]]</nowiki> <nowiki>[[WikiPedia:Samba_(Software) | Samba]]</nowiki> is an implementation of the Server Message Block (<nowiki>[[WikiPedia:Server_Message_Block | SMB]]</nowiki>)/Common Internet File System (<nowiki>[[WikiPedia:Server_Message_Block | CIFS]]</nowiki>) protocol for Unix systems, providing support for cross-platform file and printer sharing with Microsoft Windows, OS X, and other Unix systems.

Samba can be used to:
* Act as a server for SMB clients: share folders and printers, including PDF pseudo-printers so all the computers in your network may write PDF files
* Act as a domain controller in a Windows network (authenticating users, etc.)
* Do some more complex things, such as using a Windows domain controller to authenticate the users of a Linux/UNIX machine

Samba is freely available under the <nowiki>[[WikiPedia:GNU_General_Public_License | GNU General Public License]]</nowiki>. More information be found at http://www.samba.org.

== Troubleshooting ==

The first thing you should do, before looking into your conf files, is ensure that the directory you are sharing actually exists.
* <nowiki>[[http://www.samba.org/samba/docs/man/Samba-HOWTO-Collection/diagnosis.html | Samba Diagnostics]]</nowiki> - from samba.org.
* <nowiki>[[http://www.samba.org/samba/docs/man/manpages-3/pdbedit.8.html | pdbedit man page]]</nowiki> - Online version of the pdbedit manual. pdbedit is a Samba tool  that manages user accounts.

== Known issues ==

* <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/samba/+bug/252245|Unable to see Windows share hostnames in Nautilus when on WiFi]]</nowiki> - This is due to how WINS is not a protocol enabled by default in Ubuntu by earlier versions of Ubuntu. To enable this, one would execute via a terminal: <pre>
sudo nano /etc/nsswitch.conf
</pre> and change: <pre>
hosts: files
</pre> to: <pre>
hosts: files wins
</pre>
